importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the publication date of the article, marking when the UN’s WMO released its new report on global disaster alerts and the urgent need for improved early-warning systems.

The collapse of the Swiss mountain glacier in May 2025, which prompted evacuation of the village of Blatten, is cited as a real-world example of the effectiveness of early monitoring and warning systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article highlights a surge in extreme weather events throughout 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, showing how climate change is intensifying weather disasters globally.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to disaster-related deaths.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being observed in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action, which saves lives and protects economic infrastructure.
The Swiss example of glacier collapse in May 2025 led to timely evacuation of Blatten village, demonstrating the real-world value of monitoring and early alerts.
Permafrost melt and glacier instability are expected to increase risks of rockfalls and collapses, making early-warning systems vital for future climate resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global call to action to address critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capacity. With over 2 million deaths linked to weather, water, and climate hazards in the past 50 years—mostly in developing nations—the WMO stresses that early warnings are vital for saving lives and protecting infrastructure. Despite progress in early-warning systems, 50% of assessed countries still have only basic or less than basic systems, with the situation most dire in conflict-affected and fragile contexts. Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten after a predicted glacier collapse in May 2025, illustrate how timely monitoring can prevent disaster. The article emphasizes that climate change is intensifying extreme weather, with countries like Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and parts of southern Europe and the US experiencing severe floods and wildfires in 2025, reinforcing the urgent need for global investment in early-warning technologies and systems.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
